climbs.name: The Big Crack
climbs.fa: Tom Bowker, Jay Golden, Ted Hammond, Bradley White , 1981

content.description: After the big corners pitch belay. then move left on horizontal ledge to a shall 3" crack that is 30ft long. Crack is a disappointment in that it is (5-6) or easier. after crack move up low angle ledges to find a belay.
content.protection: Medium to medium large trad gear. crack has 2 bolts.
content.location: Dickey Ledge- Above and left of the big corners.

content.description: Belay in the high patch of trees on the right side of "The Beach". Layback the left side of a block and climb right over blocks to the base of a waterstreak. Ascend it, no pro, on progressivly easier climbing to the top.

From the belay climb straight up to the first bolt. Climb boldly straight up to the next bolt. The final bolt protects a crux where many have spun their wheels. Go left to eye bolt belay.**This previously said the first bolt was shared with Slab Therapy. That is not true, and was kind of confusing me. The topo posted by Glenn Cilley on the main page for the Beach shows that they do not share bolts.

From the belay climb up to a bolt then angle left to another bolt at the bottom of a right slanting ramp. Continue up left past another bolt to a flake (small cam). Easy climbing right to the eye bolts.

From the belay rock move out left past a bolt (use a shoulder sling ) continue to the old bolt (another shoulder sling) then climb up right to another bolt, step over the hang and over the dark streak, than up the steep slab past bolts. At the top traverse right past more bolts to the eye bolt anchor, rap back to the rock.
content.location: This climb is at The Beach area of Dicky ledge. Rap down from the hiking trail, from the eye bolt to the eye bolt anchor atop of The Beach climbs, rap one more time, all with one rope. Goosebumps is to the right of this and The Big Crack is to the left.

content.description: Slab climbing up the steep wave of granite
content.location: Dicky ledge Start on a ledge 50 feet off of the ground. Rap down from the hiking trail from a single eye bolt, to a 2 eye bolt anchor and rap again with one rope or climb a dirty left facing corner to get there. The left most bolted route. The three bolted routes to the right are Toms climbs. All these routs use the same anchor.

content.description: From the belay climb above the flake and run it out to the first bolt. Follow bolts to a fun top out. Go left to the eye bolt belay.

Good mostly about fifty foot slabbing in a beautiful location. This is a great hideout from the hikers chattering above. This area is very open and receives full sun for most of the day. Gear is necessary to set up a belay but otherwise the routes are mostly well protected with bolts.
